Estradiol (estrogen) is a substrate that is broken down by CYP3A4, so you'd likely see an increase in concentration if you're eating a lot of grapefruit.

The CYP3A4 enzymes are in the liver, and it metabolizes drugs from the blood irregardless of how they entered the body. So the answer to your question is that it does matter.

There is a "first pass" metabolism if you absorb drugs from the gut (because the intestinal veins drain into the portal vein system of the liver first), which is why you'll see a bigger effect from some oral drugs (because the dosing takes this into account). However, this isn't important to what you're asking.

Estriol on the other hand does not get metabolized (much) by CYP3A4, and should be mostly unaffected. CYP3A4 is a secondary pathway for estrogens in general (especially the natural ones), so the effects are much less likely to be serious relative to some of the other drugs discussed. Don't go crazy with the grapefruits, but you should be fine.

The error in this article that says that CYP3A4 is in the GI tract rather than the liver is potentially very serious (and should be corrected). CYP3A4 is entirely liver specific. Fentanyl for example is also given transdermally or by other ways to bypass the GI tract and first-pass metabolism in the liver entirely (but not subsequent passes). Inhibiting liver CYP3A4 would be potentially fatal when combined with fentanyl.

I am wondering about whether any of this matters for bio-identical estriol that's absorbed through the skin, bypassing the gut.  I certainly hope not, as I have a tree burgeoning with perfectly ripe grapefruit in my back yard.

The Chinese who came up with that aphorism had extremely strict authoritarian attitudes toward a fixed hierarchy of persons, with children and women often being mistreated.

The wife who joined her husband's family was often seen as property and abused by her husband's mother.

And then there's the foot binding, the very painful foot binding that makes it extremely difficult for a woman to walk, especially outdoors.

That's the kind of household the saying is about: Men rule, women are ordered about, boys are treated well and girls are often treated like a burden on a household.

This is not to pick on the Chinese in particular, but just about every culture has a history of racism, misogyny, authoritarianism, physical punishment of children, to a degree that we would not tolerate, to the point where many actions would be criminal.

So old sayings should be viewed in light of the culture that produced them rather than cherry-picking things that sound nice.

The Chinese have a saying that goes something like this:
Heaven is five generations in one household. Maybe Americans ought to
consider this attitude.

Productivity increases no longer lead to rising wages (at least not in the US). See, for example, Figures 4A/4U in this recent article by Derek Thompson, writing at The Atlantic: http://tinyurl.com/d25x5w4. His article, "A Giant Statistical Round-Up of the Income Inequality Crisis in 16 Charts," does a fine job of exploring the many issues to blame here: trade, globalization, technology and structural changes, union represenation, etc.

America already has incredibly high levels of productivity, especially in comparison to wages. Sure we can't compete with some of developing nations, but it would be very difficult to increase productivity. We have already reduced wages, especially when you combine them with increased productivity. Many, many salaried workers have had wages cut and have been required to do the jobs of two or more people. When you have one worker doing the job of two, that means wages have technically been cut in half. Insofar as retail workers are concerned, wages have remained stagnant while workers are doing more work in less time with hours being cut and benefits being slashed or done away with all together. Again, a form of lowering wages. All of this is happening while many companies post record profit after these same companies destroyed our economy with devious business practices.

There isn't much more workers can do. Working more for less money just isn't going to make a majority of us richer. It's going to make us poorer and more stressed out while the top 10% keeps raking it in. We have to find away to wrestle some of the money away from the top 10% and funnel it back down to the middle and lower classes so we can put it back into the economy, create demand, which creates more jobs, etc... Trickle down has been nothing but a dismal failure, so trickle up is really the only major option left.
Studies show that the productivity of the American worker is an an all-time high, while wages are lower than ever, adjusted for inflation.  Get a clue!

The US markets are integrated with the world markets. US governments cannot do anything to change the situation. Your labor wages are linked to world labor wages. You cannot have islands of prosperity today. There are four options -

1. Work in service sector. Service sector jobs are not easily transferred via internet. However the options are becoming slimmer and slimmer. I am seeing vast outsourcing of Accounting, Finance and even legal services now after the wave of call centers and IT jobs. Salary in services may be low but at least you have a job.

2. Productivity raise. Raise american workers productivity so that it gives value to the customers. Somehow the Germans have done this. They are able to give value to their customers even with their sky high wages.

3. Currency depreciation. The USD is very strong and a sharp depreciation can create the conditions. However currency devaluation effect will be temporary as all other countries will adjust theirs subsequently. The US is the market everyone else in the world is targeting for their products.

4. Lower wage levels. This is the default option and will occur if things are let to stray.

I see no silver lining on the horizon. The US will go through decades of pain of the new world order.
